title: 110_s1373
content: The Act is titled the "Building a Stronger America Act" and includes a section on the development of science parks. The "Building a Stronger America Act" includes amendments to promote the formation of science parks to cluster innovation through high technology activities. It defines a science park as a group of interrelated companies and institutions aimed at fostering innovation. The "Building a Stronger America Act" promotes the formation of science parks, which are clusters of companies and institutions in a specific area that promote real estate development, technology transfer, and partnerships. Science park infrastructure refers to facilities that support the daily economic activity of a science park. The Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980 is amended to support science parks that promote economic activity. The Stevenson-Wydler Technology Innovation Act of 1980 is amended to support science parks that promote economic activity, including Section 24 which focuses on science parks. The Secretary will award grants for feasibility studies and plans for new or expanded science parks, with a limit of $750,000 per grant. Grants will be awarded through open competition, with a focus on geographic dispersion among states of varying population densities. Advertising for competitions will be done by the Secretary. The Secretary will publish selection criteria for competitions in the Commerce Business Daily to award grants for science park development. Criteria will include job creation, funding for construction, cost matching, and types of businesses and research involved. The selection criteria for science park development grants will include types of businesses, letters of intent, expansion capacity, quality of life, workforce attraction, management, and expected risks. Authorization of appropriations for science park development grants includes funding for risk mitigation, transportation, infrastructure, and collaboration with other science parks worldwide. $7,500,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2008 to 2012. Loan guarantees of up to 80% are available for projects exceeding $10,000,000 for science park infrastructure construction. The maximum loan guarantee amounts are $50,000,000 for a single project and $500,000,000 for all projects. Recipients are chosen based on their ability to collateralize the loan through various means. Entities receiving grants are not eligible for loan guarantees. Guaranteed loans are subject to specific terms and conditions. The Secretary may prescribe terms and conditions for loans guaranteed under this subsection. The final maturity of such loans may not exceed 30 years and 32 days or 90 percent of the useful life of the asset being financed. Loans cannot be subordinated to other debts in case of default, and the lender must be deemed responsible by the Secretary for a loan to be guaranteed. The lender must be responsible and ensure reasonable loan servicing and protection of the US financial interest. Loans cannot be guaranteed if the income is tax-exempt or if significant collateral is provided. The guarantee serves as conclusive evidence of proper guarantee issuance. The Secretary must ensure that loan guarantees are properly obtained and meet specific criteria. Explicit standards are prescribed for assessing credit risk, and credit assistance is only extended if there is a reasonable assurance of repayment. New loan guarantees cannot be committed without meeting these requirements. The Secretary must ensure that loan guarantees meet specific criteria and credit risk standards before being committed. If a borrower defaults on a guaranteed loan, the Secretary will pay the holder a specified percentage of the loss. The Secretary will be subrogated to the rights of the payment recipient and can recover payments from the borrower. The Attorney General will enforce any rights of the United States resulting from guarantees issued. The section allows forbearance for the borrower approved by the Secretary. The Secretary has the authority to manage property acquired under the guaranteed loan, including completing, renovating, and selling it. The Comptroller General will review subsidy estimates within 2 years of the section's enactment. The Secretary can manage acquired property under the guaranteed loan. The Comptroller General will review subsidy estimates within 2 years of enactment. A review of subsidy estimates for loan guarantees must be conducted, and a report submitted to Congress. Loan guarantees under this subsection cannot be made after September 30, 2012. Authorization of appropriations includes funds for guaranteeing loans and administrative expenses. National Academy of Sciences evaluation is required. The Secretary must have the National Academy of Sciences evaluate science park development every 3 years and submit a report with recommendations to promote and facilitate science parks in the United States. Additionally, the Secretary must report to Congress every third year on the activities related to this section. The Secretary is required to submit reports to Congress every 3 years with recommendations from the National Academy of Sciences to promote science park development in the United States. Additionally, regulations must be prescribed within 1 year of enactment to implement this section.
